title: The rise of the global stakeholder
text:
After visiting several garment factories in Bangladesh recently, I can say that there has been a significant improvement in standards. This was driven by an Accord on Fire and Building Safety signed in the aftermath of the fire by international labour unions and major clothing brands, including local retailers such as Target and Myer.

Granted, wages remain low to maintain their competitive advantage. Undoubtedly there are operations that don’t follow the guidelines. But an overall sense of improvement is palpable.

It is unlikely that any change would have happened without a global outcry and the threat of consumer boycotts. In striving for a more ethical capitalism, one of the biggest challenges is merely identifying the various stakeholders in a dispersed, global economy.

Take the frontline employees. While we watch the decline of local manufacturing, but the working classes have been reconstructed worldwide, be they garment workers in Bangladesh, car or smartphone assembly workers in China or Thailand, or foreign labourers on the construction sites of the Middle East.

Regulation is easier when all the elements exists under a national banner, but changes in global industry make this difficult.

In the case of fast fashion, it took a monumental tragedy to even make us aware of the nature of the supply chain – an arms-length relationship between retailers and suppliers, a regulatory regime of voluntary ethical codes set by multinationals and a lack of protection for organised labour in low-income countries.

While it is quite a burden for customers to research every aspect of the products and services they buy, firms are far more aware of the risks that disasters like Rana Plaza present to their brands.

The lesson of Rana plaza is that stakeholder and shareholder interests need not be zero sum. But it is not always clear that shareholders will be aware of all the stakeholders.

It was the legendary boss of General Electric, Jack Welch, who criticised the Milton Friedman idea that businesses should stick to shareholder returns alone: “Shareholder value is the dumbest idea in the world. Shareholder value is a result, not a strategy … your main constituencies are your employees, your customers and your products".

There will need to be significant improvements in disclosure around the treatment of workers, community investment and environmental impact so that the market can reward leaders and penalise stragglers.

The overseas customer remains critical in driving this transparency, especially as both work and consumption in advanced economies are becoming more purpose-driven.

Just as the system has lifted hundreds of millions out of poverty across the developing world, the garment workers support their families or educate their children in the hope of something better. There is no question that these employees need capitalism to work.

The tide against shareholder primacy underlines a recognition that every link in the value chain that creates goods or services must be fairly treated for the global economic system to retain trust and sustainability. But there is still a knowledge gap in implementing this version of a truly inclusive capitalism.

Tanveer Ahmed is a practising psychiatrist.
description: Capitalism is lifting a new globalised working class out of poverty. But it needs Western stakeholders to pay attention too.
